name: FM Radio Songs, Part X Quiz / Test | Music by Year | 10 Questions

questions.text: In 1973, New Riders of the Purple Sage hit the FM radio airwaves with a song called "Panama _____."
questions.explanation:
Red.

	New Riders of the Purple Sage hailed from San Francisco and played country / rock style music. In 1973, this band received considerable FM radio airplay with an upbeat ditty called "Panama Red"- a tribute to the infamous and potent cannabis plant. John Dawson, David Nelson and Dave Torbert supplied vocals; Buddy Cage played some nifty pedal steel guitar music on "Panama Red." The New Riders sang these lyrics: "Panama Red, Panama RedHe'll steal your womanThen he'll rob your headPanama Red, Panama RedHis white horse Mescalino comes breezin' through town..."

questions.text: In 1972, The Kinks released "Celluloid Heroes." Which one of these Hollywood stars was NOT mentioned in this song's lyrics?
questions.explanation:
Judy Garland.

	"Celluloid Heroes" was Ray Davies' epic effort to pay tribute to some of Hollywood's biggest stars. This song appeared on the 1972 Kinks' album "Everybody's in Show Biz." Davies mentioned several legendary movie stars in "Celluloid Heroes": Greta Garbo ("She looks so weak and fragile"), Bela Lugosi ("He's liable to turn and bite"), and Bette Davis ("Hers was such a lonely life"). However, singer / actress Judy Garland was not discussed in the tune's lyrics.

questions.text: In 1977, the group Fleetwood Mac released a song called "Go Your Own Way." Which popular album contained this classic FM radio song?
questions.explanation:
Rumours.

	Fleetwood Mac achieved platinum success in 1977 with the album "Rumours." This record became an international number one hit album and featured such songs as "Go Your Own Way" and "Don't Stop." Band member Lindsey Buckingham supposedly wrote "Go Your Own Way" after his breakup with fellow Fleetwood Mac singer Stevie Nicks. The album "Penguin" appeared in 1973, "Heroes Are Hard to Find" was released in 1974, and "Tusk" appeared in 1979.

questions.text:
Please complete this line from Neil Young's 1972 song "Heart of Gold":

"I've been to Hollywood, I've been to _______
I crossed the ocean for a heart of gold..."
questions.explanation:
Redwood.

	Neil Young's song "Heart of Gold" appeared on his successful 1972 album "Harvest." The Canadian born singer took "Heart of Gold" all the way to the top of the U.S. singles charts, and "Harvest" became a staple on FM radio stations. Young sang, "I've been to Hollywood, I've been to Redwood / I crossed the ocean for a heart of gold..."

questions.text: Which British band achieved FM radio success in the USA in 1977 with the song "Couldn't Get It Right"?
questions.explanation:
Climax Blues Band.

	Climax Blues Band hailed from Stafford, England, and hit the U.S. FM radio airwaves in 1977 with a song called "Couldn't Get It Right." The band was led by some talented musicians such as Colin Cooper and Pete Haycock. Climax Blues Band sang these lyrics: "I kept on looking for a wayTo take me through the nightBut I couldn't get it rightNo, I couldn't get it right..."

questions.text: In 1978, The Atlanta Rhythm Section recorded a song called "_______ Jam."
questions.explanation:
Champagne.

	The Atlanta Rhythm Section released a song and album called "Champagne Jam" in 1978. The song "Champagne Jam" featured some tasty southern rock and blues sounds; every member of ARS got the chance to show off his musical ability. Ronnie Hammonds was the lead vocalist on "Champagne Jam", Dean Daughtry played keyboards; J.R. Cobbs and Barry Bailey were the guitarists; Robert Nix played drums; and Paul Goddard played the bass.

questions.text: In 1973, "Smokin' In the Boys Room" was a popular FM radio song for a group called Brownsville _______.
questions.explanation:
Station.

	The song "Smokin' In the Boys Room" was recorded by Brownsville Station in 1973. Brownsville Station came from Michigan and featured the guitar and vocal work of Cub Koda. In the USA, "Smokin" rose to number three in the singles charts and received considerable ariplay on FM radio stations across the country.

"Are you ready, Steve? Uh-huh.
Andy? Yeah. Mike? Yeah.
Alright, fellas- let's go!"

Which 1973 song by the British band Sweet opened with the above words?
questions.explanation:
The Ballroom Blitz.

	The English band Sweet achieved FM radio success in 1973 with the song "The Ballroom Blitz." The opening words to this tune referred to band members Steve Priest (bass), Andy Scott (guitar), and Mick Tucker (drums). Brian Connolly sang lead vocals on this hard-rocking song. In the USA, "The Ballroom Blitz" climbed to the number spot on the singles charts. Sweet sang these words: "And the man in the back said everyone attackAnd it turned into a ballroom blizAnd the girl in the corner said boy I wanna warn youIt'll turn into a ballroom blitz, ballroom blitz..." The Hollies recorded "Long Cool Woman", The Sex Pistols sang "God Save the Queen", and The Pretenders did "Brass in Pocket."

questions.text: In 1976-77, Manfred Mann's Earth Band had considerable success with the song "Blinded By the Light." Which singer of "Born to Run" composed this tune?
questions.explanation:
Bruce Springsteen.

	Manfred Mann's Earth Band recorded the Bruce Springsteen composition "Blinded By the Light" in 1976. Springsteen had previously recorded this song for his 1973 "Greetings From Asbury Park N.J." album. The Manfred Mann version of "Blinded" soared to the top of the U.S. singles charts in early 1977 and featured the musicianship of Manfred Mann (keyboards), Dave Flett (guitar), and Chris Thompson (vocals).

questions.text: In 1970, The Beatles released their "Let It Be" album. Which George Harrison song on this collection made reference to the legendary guitarist Elmore James?
questions.explanation:
For You Blue.

	The George Harrison composition "For You Blue" was one of the last songs ever recorded by The Beatles- sometime in January 1970. This song featured John Lennon's playing a lap steel guitar. In the middle section of "For You Blue", Harrison complimented Lennon by saying "Go, Johnny, go!" and "Elmore James got nothin' on this baby!" James was famous for his bottleneck guitar technique. Harrison sang, "Because you're sweet and lovely, girl / I love you. Because you're sweet and lovely, girl, it's true..."
